sp.p: Angelo, give him not too much time with me, for fear of the worst, but go presently to the back gate, and use my husband's knock, then will I presently thrust him into my coal-house: and there shall the old fleshmonger fast for his iniquity. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Well said mine own Frank i'faith, we shall trim him betwixt us, I for the most slovenly case in the town; she, for the most sluttish place in the house: never was old horseman so notoriously ridden; well, I will presently knock him into the coal-house, and then haste to Lodovico, to know when he shall be released. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Lodovico with a ladder of ropes, Aurelio, (Aemilia above.)

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Here's thy ladder, and there's thy gallows, thy mistress is thy hangman, and must take thee down: this is the terrace where thy sweet heart tarries; what wouldst thou call it in rhyme?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Celestial sphere, wherein more beauty shines.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Room for a passion.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Then on Dardanian Ida, where the pride
Of heavens selected beauties strived for prize.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay you shall know, we have watered our houses in Helicon. I cannot abide this talking and undoing poetry, leave your mellifluous numbers: yonder's a sight will steal all reason from your rhyme I can tell you; down of your knees you slave, adore. Now let's hear you invocate, oh the saple hams of a lover, go to, do not, stand up close, for she must not see you yet, though she know you are here.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Cousin Lodowick?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Who calls Lodowick?

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: What tempest hath cast you on this solitary shore? Is the party come?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
The party? now a plague of your modesty, are
your lips too nice to name Aurelio?

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Well, is he come then?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: He, which he? 'sfoot name your man with a mischief to you, I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Was there ever such a wildbrain? Aurelio.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Aurelio? Lord how loath you are to let any sound of him come out an you, you hold him so dear within, I'll present her with a sight, will startle her nicety a little better; hold you, fasten the end of this ladder I pray.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Now Jesus bless us, why cousin, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Go to you spirit of a feather, be not so soft hearted, leave your nicety, or by this hemp I'll so hamper thy affections in the halter of thy lover's absence, making it up in a Gordian knot of forgetfulness, that no Alexander of thy allurements, with all the swords of thy sweet words, shall ever cut in pieces.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Lord, how you roll in your roperipe terms.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Go to, tell me, will you fasten the ladder or no?

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: I know not what I should say t'ee: I will fasten it, so only yourself will come up.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Only myself will come up then.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Nay sweet coz, swear it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: If I should swear thou wouldst curse me: take my word in a halter's name, and make the ladder as fast to the terrace, as thou wouldst be to Aurelio.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Nay see if he do not make me give over again?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Was there ever such a blue kitling? fasten it now, or by heaven thou dost lose me for ever.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Well sir, remember your word; I will fasten it, but i'faith coz, is not the gentleman, and his parting choler parted yet?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I'faith with much ado:

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Nay, nay, choose him; I shall live, if they be not: and if I live till his choler kill me, I shall live till he leave loving me, and that will be a good while first.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Lord, lord, who has informed you of such amorous
fervency in him: are you so confident in his kindness?

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Nay by my troth, 'tis but a careless confidency neither, which always last longer than that which is timorous: well coz, here I have fastened it for your pleasure; but alas, the fear of my father's coming does so distract me that I scarce know what I do or say.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Your father? dost think we would venture all this preparation, and not make him safe?

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: But are you sure he is safe?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Am I sure this is Aurelio? look upon him wench, is it not thy love? thy life? come sir, mount.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: O cousin Lodwick, do you thus cousin and betray me?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Coz, coz, thou hast acted thy dissembling part long enough, in the most modest judgement, and passing naturally: give over with thy credit then, unmask thy love, let her appear in her native simplicity, strive to conceal her no longer from thy love, for I must needs tell thee he knows all.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: What does he know?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why all that thou toldest me, that thou lovest him more than he can love thee, that thou hast set up thy resolution, in despite of friends or foes, weals or woes, to let him possess thee wholly, and that thou didst woo me to bring him hither to thee: all this he knows; that it was thy device to prepare this ladder, and in a word, all the speech that passed betwixt thee and me he knows, I told him every word truly and faithfully god's my judge.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Now was there ever such an immodest creature?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Via, with all vain modesty, leave this colouring, and strip thy love stark naked, this time is too precious to spend vainly; mount I say.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Model of heavenly beauty.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
'Sounds, wilt thou melt into rhyme a the tother side? shall we have lines? change thy style for a ladder, this
will bring thee to Parnassus, up I say.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Unworthy I t'approach the furthest step to that felicity that shines in her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: O spurblind affection, I have seen a fellow, to a worse end ascend a ladder with a better will, and yet this is in the way of marriage, and they say, marriage and hanging have both one constellation. To approve the which old saying, see if a new ladder make 'em not agree.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Peace, somebody comes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: That you heard, was but a mouse, so boy I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O sacred goddess, whatsoe'er thou art
That in mere pity to preserve a soul
From undeserved destruction, hast vouchsafed
To take Aemilia's shape.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What a poetical sheep is this? 'slife, will you stand rhyming there upon a stage, to be an eye-mark to all that pass? is there not a chamber by? withdraw I say for shame, have you no shame in you? here will come somebody presently I lay my life on't.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Dear mistress, to avoid that likely danger,
Vouchsafe me only private conference,
And 'tis the fullness of my present hopes. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Aurelio, occasion is bald, take her by the forelock; so, so. In Hymen's name get you together, here will I stand sentinel. This is the back gate to Honorio's house, which shall be Aurelio's, if God give him grace to weep for his father's death in time. And in this garden, if I could see the chaste Lucrece, or the affable mistress temperance, I might (Thus wrapped in my cloak) steal a little courtship through the chink of a pale. But indeed I think it safer to sit closer, and so to cloud the sum of my visnomy, that no eye discern it. (He sits down, and muffles himself in his cloak.)so be it, that's my resolution. Now to my contemplation, this is no pandarism, is it?
No, for there is neither money nor credit proposed or expected, and besides there is no unlawful act intended, no not this same lasciva actio animi: I think for his part, much less hers: go to, let me do my kinswoman, and her sex right, sit at rest with me then reputation, and conscience, fall asleep with the world, but this same idle attendance is the spite of it, idleness is accounted with other men a sin, to me 'tis a penance, I was begotten in a stirring season, for now hath my soul a thousand fancies in an instant, as what wench dreams on when she lies on her back, when one hen lays an egg and another sits it, whether that hen shall mother that chicken? If my bull leap your cow, is not the calf yours? yes no doubt, for aedificium cedit solo says the lawyer: and then to close all comes in a sentence, non omnia possumus omnes: for some are born to riches, others to verses, some to be bachelors, others to be cuckolds, some to get crowns, and others to spend 'em, some to get children, and others to keep 'em: and all this is but idleness, would to God I had some scurvy poem about me to laugh at,(Enter temperance.)but mark, yonder's a motion to be seen.

sp.speaker: Temperance
sp.p: Yonder he sits i'faith, well done true love, good signior Leonoro, he keeps promise the best, he does not see me yet.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'Tis the staid madam temperance, a pretty pinnace she has been in her days, and in her nights too, for her burden, and reasonable good under sail, and see she hath discovered a sail, see, see, she hales him in, ha? 'tis this way to the rewards, slight 'tis this way: I hope the bawd knows not me, and yet I know not, she may be a witch, for a whore she was before I knew her, a bawd I have known her any time this dozen years, the next step to honour then is a witch, because of nature, for where the whore ends, the bawd begins, and the corruption of a bawd, is the generation of a witch. And Pythagoras holds opinion, that a witch turns to a wild cat, as an old ostler turns to an ambling nag. Enter Leonoro muffled in his cloak with Lyonell.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: This is the back gate, where temperance should meet me at this hour.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: I wonder she fails, for I see her not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Why sits that fellow there trow? come let's hover hereabouts 'twill not be long ere we encounter. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: So, now this riddle is expounded, this bawd took me for this adventurer whom (Twenty to one) she attended, to waft him into Lucretia's chamber, what a beast was I, not to apprehend this advantage, thus muffled as I am, she could not have perceived me till I had been in, and I might safely have stayed a while without endangering my lovers:(Enter temperance stealing along the stage.)'slight she takes me still for her first man.

sp.speaker: Temperance
sp.p: Come, come, gingerly for God's sake, gingerly.

sp.speaker: L●o.
sp.p: See Lyonell, yet she is not come, and the privy attendant is gone.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: I wonder what it was.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I fear me some other client of hers, whom she prefers before me, come, we must not linger here too long together, we'll enter on this backside, to the emperor's head, where we will stay a little, and then make the last trial of this bawd's honesty. (Enter Quintiliano, Giovenelli, and Fannio in their doublet and hose.)

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Come ancient, let's leave our company a little, and air ourselves in this backside. — who goes there?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: A friend.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: The word.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: God save you captain Quintiliano.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Shoot him ancient, a spy, the word's the emperor's head, and thither you shall go sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Pardon me good captain.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: Come, be not retrograde to our desires.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I attend a friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Thou'st attended him already, I am witness to't, deny't and he dare, whatsoever he be, and he shall attend thee another while, and he will: thou'rt as good a man as he, and he be the Duke himself, for a clarissimo; entertain him ancient, bid the clarissimo, welcome, I'll call a drawer, and we'll have some wine in this arbour. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: You're very welcome signior clarissimo, desire you more acquaintance sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My name is Leonoro sir, and indeed I scarce know you.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: No sir, and you know me, you must know as much as I know, for scientia and scientificus is all one; but that's all one, in truth sir, you shall not spend a penny here, I had money, I thank God even now, and peradventure shall have again ere we part, I have sent to a friend of mine.

div.stage: (Enter Quintilliano and a drawer with a cup of wine and a towel.)

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Here honourable clarissimo, I drink to thee.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Thank you good captain.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, winesucker, what have you filled us here, balderdash? taste Leonoro.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: methinks 'tis sack.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Let us taste sir, 'tis claret, but it has been fetch't again with aqua vitae.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: 'Slight methinks t'as taken salt water, who drew this wine you rogue?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: My fellow Sam drew it sir, the wine's a good neat wine, but you love a pleasanter grape, I'll fit your palate sir. (He stands close.)

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Is this thy boy Leonoro?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: For fault of a better sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Afore heaven 'tis a sweet faced child, methinks he should show well in woman's attire: and he took her by the lily white hand, and he laid her upon a bed. I'll help thee to three crowns a week for him, and she can act well. Hast ever practised my pretty Ganymede?

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: No, nor never mean sir.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p:
Mean sir? No marry captain, there will never
be mean in his practice I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: O finely taken; sirrah, clarissimo, this fellow was an arrant ass this forenoon, afore he came to be an ancient.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: But where's your lieutenant captain?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: 'Sounds man, he's turned swaggerer.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Swaggerer by this light he; and is in the next room writing a challenge to this tall gentleman my ancient here.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What, mutinous in your own company?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: 'Sfoot man, who can bridle the ass's valour?

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: 'Sblood and any man think to bridle me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: But what was the quarrel?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why sir, because I entertained this gentleman for my ancient, (Being my dear friend and an excellent scholar) he takes pepper ith' nose and sneezes it out upon my ancient; now sir (He being of an uncoal-carrying spirit) falls foul on him, calls him gull openly; and ever since I am fain to drink with 'em in two rooms, dare not let 'em come together for my life, but with pen and inkhorns, and so my lieutenant is in the next chamber casting cold ink upon the(Enter Innocentio.)flame of his courage, to keep him from the blot of cowardice, see where he comes with his challenge: good clarissimo hold my ancient.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Good ancient, forbear in a tavern.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Revenge noble lieutenant, hast thou done it?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: 'Slight I think I have peppered him, but 'twas his own seeking you know.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: That's certain.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: 'Sounds my seeking sir?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Hold him Leonoro; and if it be possible, persuade him to hear the challenge from the enemies own mouth.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I'll undertake he shall captain: good ancient let me entreat you.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: Well sir, because you're a stranger to me, you shall do more with me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Thank you good ancient.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Read fiery lieutenant, read boy, legibly.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Here it is sir: signior Giovenelli, it is not ignorant unto you, that even now you crossed me over the coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: I did so sir: I will not deny it I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Good ancient peace.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: And that openly, or else it would never have grieved me.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: That openly was all indeed.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: And moreover, very unreverendly to call me gull, and ass to my face: and therefore, though I held it good discretion in me to wink at the blow, not seeing to take notice of it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Good discretion in deed.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Yet know that I will have satisfaction from you.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: Well sir, and you shall.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Nay good ancient hear him.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: And desire you to send me word, whether you will maintain it or no, hoping that you will not offer that discourtesy to do me wrong, and stand to it when you have done.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That were foul indeed.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: And as for the words, in that you called me gull, and ass to my face, resolve me by letter (For I do not think fit we should meet) first whether you spoke any such words or no: and secondly by whom you mean 'em. And it by me (As I think you durst not) confess you are sorry for 'em: and if I have offended you, I heartily ask you forgiveness. And so farewell.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Afore heaven ancient, this would have tickled you, but good Leonoro, and thou beest a right clarissimo, let's make 'em friends, and drink to one another: 'sfoot, we have no wine here methinks , where's this aperner?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Have you mended your hand sir.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: I captain, and if this please not your taste, either you or I cannot taste a cup of wine.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Sounds you're very saucy sir, here lieutenant, drink to thy ancient, and void mutinies with your officer, martial law is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Is he content I should drink to him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: He is I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Why then ancient good luck t'ee.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: Let come lieutenant, I pledge you.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why so, now my company is cured again, afore 'twas wounded. Come honourable clarissimo, let's retire to our strength, taste a fresh carouse or two, and then march home with music. Tapster, call us in some music.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: I will sir.

div.head: Actus quartus.
div.stage: Enter Quintiliano, Leonoro, Innocentio, Lionello, Fannio, with music.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Strike up scrapers, honourable clarissimo, and thy sweet Adonis, adieu, remember our device at the show soon.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I will not fail captain, farewell t'ee both: come Lionel, now let us try the truth of madam temperance, and see if she attend us.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: I hope by this time she remembers her promise sir. Exeunt leo. and Lio.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: How now lieutenant, where's my ancient?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Marry captain you've left him casting the reckoning ith' chimney.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p:
Why then his purse and his stomach will be empty
together, and so I cashier him; let the scholar report at Padua, that Venice has other manner of learning belongs to it: what does his continuum et contiguum here? let 'em go to the ink pot and beware of the wine pot.
Fill red cheeked Bacchus, let the Bordeaux grape
Skip like la voltos in their swelling veins.
Te dan, dan tidle, te dan de dan tidle diddle, etc.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: O God captain that I could dance so.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: He took her by (Strike up fiddlers) the lily white hand and he laid her upon the bed. O what a spirit have I now? I long to meet a sergeant in this humour, I would but have one whiff at one of these same pewter buttoned shoulder-clappers, to try whether this chopping knife or their pestels were the better weapons. Here's a blade boy, it was the old Duke's first predecessors; I'll tell thee what lieutenant, this sword has dubbed more knights than thy knife has opened oysters.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Is't possible captain, and methinks it stands a little.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p:
No matter for that, your best metalled blades will stand soonest: so, now we have attained our mansion house. At which I'll sing a verse shall break the doors. O noble
Hercules, let no Stygian lake.
Te dan dan tidle, te dan de dan tidle diddle, etc. farewell scrapers, your reward now shall be that I will not cut your strings nor break your fiddles, via, away.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Come captain, let's enter, I long to see my mistress, I warrant she's a heavy gentlewoman for your absence.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: 'Sfoot she's an ass, honour woos me, preferment calls me, and I must lie pampered in a wench's lap, because she dotes on me. Honour says no, lieutenant, pugna pro patria, we must to't i'faith and seek our portion amongst the scratched faces.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo
sp.p: Within.mistress, mistress, is he gone?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Who's that calls there?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: I heard nobody .

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: No? there was one called mistress: I say who called mistress, 'sblood I hope I am not drunk.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: In truth sir I heard nobody .

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: I tell thee I smelled a voice here in my entry, 'sfoot I'll make it smell worse and cheer it again.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: O me, he'll draw upon his own shadow in this humour, if it take the wall of him. Follow him Fannio, look he do no harm for God sake.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Help, help, help.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Name of God, what's there to do? (Enter Quintil. and Lorenzo.)

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Good captain do not hurt me.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Sounds is hell broke loose? why snail, though you can sing songs and do things snail, I must not allow ye to creep into my wife's coal-house, what snail into my withdrawing chamber?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I beseech your worship hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: O snail, this is a hard case; no room serve your turn, but my wife's coal-house, and her other house of office annexed to it? A privy place for herself, and me sometimes, and will you use it being a stranger? 'slight how comes this about? up sirrah and call your mistress.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A plague of all disguises. Exit Fannio.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Alas poor snail, what didst thou make here?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I protest sir for no harm, my mistress called me in to sweep her chimney, and because I did it not to her mind, she made me do penance in her coal-house.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Search him captain and see, if he have stolen nothing.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Kill me, hang me, if I have.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Yes snail, and besides I hear complaints of you, you're an old luxurious hummerer about wench's snail, does this become your gravity sir? Lieutenant, fetch me a coal-sack, I'll put him in it and hang him up for a sign.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I beseech your worship be good to me.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Good captain pardon him, since he has done nothing but swept your chimney worse than my mistress would have it swept, he will do it better another time.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Well snail, at this gentleman's request, (To whom I can deny nothing) I release you for this once, but let me take you no more thus I advise you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Not while I live good captain.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Hence, trudge you drudge, go away.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A plague of all disguises. Exit Lorenzo.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: I have looked about all the house for my mistress sir, but I cannot find her.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Go then, look all about the town for her too; come in lieutenant, let's repose a little after our liquor.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Dear life, be resolute, that no respect
Heighted above the compass of your love,
Depress the equal comforts it retains;
For since it finds a firm consent in both,
And both our births and years agree so well,
If both our aged parents should refuse,
For any common object of the world,
To give their hands to ours, let us resolve
To live together like our lives and souls.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.l: I am resolved my love; and yet alas,
So much affection to my father's will
Consorts the true desires I bear to you,
That I would have no spark of our love seen,
Till his consent be asked, and so your fathers.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: So runs the mutual current of my wish,
And with such stayed and circumspect respects,
We may so serve and govern our desires,
That till fit observation of our fathers,
prefer the motion to them; we may love
Without their knowledge and the skill of any,
Save only of my true friend Lodowick.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.l: I wonder where he is.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Not far I know,
For in some place, he watcheth to prevent
The feared danger of your father's presence.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Sounds stay for the love of your honour sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A plague of all disguises Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What reason have you to curse them? has not one of them kept you safe from the shame of the world, as much as a poor disguise might do; but when your ridiculous fears will cast it off, even while it is on, so running through the streets, that they rise all in an uproar after you ▪ alas what is the poor disguise to blame sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Well then fortune is to blame, or some thing; come as thou didst help to daub me, help to cleanse me, I prithee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Let alone a while sir for God's sake, I'll go see whether the captain be gone from home or no.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Out upon that course Angelo; I am frighted out of it, come enter my house, enter.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What, will you enter your house sir afore you know who is in it: keep yourself close, and let me first enter and discover.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I know there is nobody .

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: You cannot know it sir, I heard even now that divers of the senate were determined to come and sit in counsel there.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A tale, a very tale Angelo, enter for the love of heaven, enter and unsmother me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What shall I do? my poor master is bewrayed, oh that same faithless Lodowick, that could drown the swaggering captain no better in his drunkenness; alas how should I salve this? Exit.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How now? whom do I see? my daughter and a younker together? passion of death, hell and damnation, what lecherous Capricorn reigns this unhappy day? old and young in a predicament? O fie of filthy sin and concupiscence, I will conceal my rage a while that it may break forth in fury; I'll shift me presently Angelo, and go fetch the Provost.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: O unspeakable madness, will you for ever dishonour your daughter, and in her yourself sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Talk not to me, out upon this abominable concupiscence, the pride of the flesh, this witchcraft of the devil: talk not to me, justice cries out an't in the streets, and I will see it punished, come good Angelo to help to shift me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I'll follow you sir instantly; master, master.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Angelo? what news?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Miserable master, cast down your ladder, and come down instantly.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Alas, why, Angelo is my father coming.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Let us not talk but come down I say.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Dear life, farewell, we'll shortly meet again,
So parts the dying body from the soul;
As I depart from my Aemilia.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.l: So enter frighted souls to the low world,
As my poor spirit upon this sudden doubt,
What may succeed this danger.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Come away, you'll be whipped anon for your amourosity, hast for shame haste, etc.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Once more and ever, fare my dear life well.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Leave your amorous congees and get you in dame ▪
sir you and I will talk as 'twere betwixt the pales, now, get you and shift you of this suit presently.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Shift me Angelo? why man?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Ask me no questions, but go home and shift you presently, and when I have done a little business here within, I'll come and tell you my device: there hath more chanced than you are aware of, and then I can stand to tell you; away therefore presently go home and shift you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Very good sir, I will be ruled by you, and after learn the mysteries. Exit Aurel.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Now will I let the little squire shift and cleanse himself without me, that he may be longer about fetching the Provost, and in the mean time will I take my master's suit (Of which the little squire took note) and put it on my sweet heart Francischina, who shall presently come and supply my master's place, with his mistress; for the little squire amazed with his late affrights and this sudden offenceful spectacle of his daughter, took no certain note who it was that accosted her; for if he had, he would have blamed me for my master, only the colour of his garment sticks in his fancy, which when he shall still see where he left it, he will still imagine the same person wears it, and thus shall his daughter's honour and my masters be preserved with the finest sugar of invention. And when the little squire discovers my sweet heart, she shall swear, she so disguised herself, to follow him, for her love to him; ha, ha ha, oh the wit of man when it has the wind of a woman. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Lodovico and Lucretia, with rapiers fighting.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Hold, hold, I pray thee hold; I yield my rapier,
Let my submission, my presumption salve.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Ignoble Lodwick, should I take thy life,
It were amends too little for the wrong.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O the precious heavens:
How was I guled? haud, hide thyself for shame.
And henceforth have an eye before thy fingers.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Well do not jest it out, for I protest
If this disguise, which my inhumane fate
Puts on my proper sex, be by thy means
Seen through, by any other than thyself,
The quarrel twixt us shall be more than mortal.
And thy dishonour to a friendless stranger
(Exiled his native country, to remain
Thrall to the mercy of such unknown maids
As fortune makes the rulers of my life)
Shall spread itself beyond my misery,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay, mix not cause of mirth with passion,
Do me the grace t'unfold thy name and state,
And tell me what my whole estate may do,
To salve this wrong unwittingly I did thee?
And set the plaintiff thoughts of thy hard fate
In such peace, as my friendship may procure:
And if I fail thee, let Jove fail my soul,
When most this earth makes it need help of heaven.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: In the more than temper my late rage
And show your virtues perfectly derived
From the Venetian noblesse; for my name
It is Lucretio, which to fit this habit
I turned Lucretia: the rest that rests
To be related of my true estate,
I'll tell some other time: lest now your presence
Might dumbly tell it (If it should be seen)
To all the world, or else make it suspect
My female life of lightness: then with thanks
And vow of all true friendship, for th'amends
Your kindness makes me, take your sword again,
And with it while I live the power of mine
In any honoured use shall command.
Then till we meet, and may laugh at this error,
I'll once more try the free peace of my chamber. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Do so sweet friend: a plague of gingerly?
Where is that stale and fulsome gingerly,
She brought me to a fury, I'll be sworn
Rather than man or woman: a flat beating:
I found her supposed mistress fast asleep,
Put her to the touchstone, and she provea man.
He waked, and with a more than manly spirit
Flew in my face, and gave me such a dash
In steed of kissing, of these liquorish lips
That still my teeth within them bled I swearHe spits.
Gingerly, gingerly, a plague a you. He spits again.
But now how does my lovers on the terrace?

div.stage: Enter Aurelio with Angelo, shifting his apparel.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Hold, take my doublet too, my hat and all, and quickly hie thee to thy sweet.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: 'Zounds, see sir see, your proper sentinel, that when you needed him, gave you a slip.

sp.speaker: Anr.
sp.p: Friend Lodovico, by my life, well welcome to this my father's backside.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Well sir, well, I would I had kissed almost your father's backside so I had never known it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: A my life he faints extremely, he left you even now to purchase him the amorous interview of your fair coz Lucretia that lies here.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: God's me, sweet friend, wouldst thou use such a slight to any one that lay within my walk? who was thy mean to her?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I lay my life, tame madam temperance, the notorious pandar.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: S'fut friend, what a notorious oversight was that? and what a violent injury unto thy friend?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
A plague upon you both, you scurvy hind, have
you no gull but me to whet your wit upon?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: My friend a privy lover? I'd have sworn
Love might spend all his shafts at butterflies
As well as at his bosom.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: 'Twas your fault then,
For I have noted a most faithful league
Betwixt him and his barber now of late,
And all the world may see, he does not leave
One hair on his smooth chin, as who should say,
His hapless love was gone against the hair.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: 'Sblood and these rogues knew how I was deceived,
They'd stout me into motley, by this light.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Well sir, I ever thought y'ad the best wit
Of any man in Venice next mine own,
But now I'll lay the bucklers at your feet,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: A pox upon thee, tame your bald hewed tongue,
Or by the lord of heaven I'll pull it out.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O my sweet friend, come I'll know more of this,
And tell thee all our fortune, hence good Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: O, if this man had patience to his brain,
A man might load him till he smart again. Exit Ang.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Patience worthy friend, he knows you love him for his knavish wit. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Thou shalt not stay sweet temperance, tell us the manner of our war and we'll leave thee presently.

sp.speaker: Temperance
sp.p:
Why that perl's man Lodowick, according to your appointment was jump at three with me, just, been full at your hour; muffled as I willed you, e'en your fashion and your very leg for all the earth, and followed me in so gingerly, that by my troth I must needs say, he was worthy the pleasuring; but in what a taking was I when I perceived
his voice? And when I saw my mistress and he together by the ears?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What did thy mistress fight with him?

sp.speaker: Temperance
sp.p: O King a heaven, she ran upon his naked weapon the most finely that ever lived, and I ran away in a swoon for fear.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Has she a good courage?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: It seems she is too honest for our companies, a little more good temperance.

sp.speaker: Temperance
sp.p: And when he saw me, he called me punk, and pander, and doxy, and the vilest nicknames as if I had been an errand naughty-pack.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter temperance, he's known and thou art known.

sp.speaker: Temperance
sp.p: I thank heaven for it, and there's all indeed, I can stay no longer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Farewell honest temperance: how was it possible, Lodovico should fit all these circumstances without the confederacy and treachery of this beldame? well Lodovico must satisfy this doubt when I see him.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: That will be at the may night show at signior Honorio's.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I would not meet him there, I shall offend him, but there I must needs be, and have thee disguised like a woman.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Me sir?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No remedy, the captain Quintilliano and I have devised it to gull his lieutenant: for thou shalt dance with him, we will thrust him upon thee, and then for his courting and gifts, which we will tell him he must win thee withal, I hope thou wilt have wit enough to receive the tone, and pay him again with the tother, come Lionell let me see how naturally thou canst play the woman. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Better then you think for.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Come lieutenant, this nap has set a nap of sobriety upon our brains, now let's sit here and consult, what course were best for us to take in this dangerous mansion of man's life.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: I am for you i'faith captain and you go to consult once.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: I know it lieutenant, say then what think'st thou? we talked of employment, of action, of honour, of a company and so forth.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Did we so captain?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Did we so ass? 'sfoot, wert thou drunk afore thou wentest to the tavern, that thou hast now forgotten it?

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Cry you mercy good captain, I remember I am your lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Well sir, and so thou shalt be called still, and I captain, though we never lead other company then a sort of quart pots.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Shall we captain, byth' mass then let's never have other company in deed.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why now thou'rt wise, and haste a mind transformed with main right, and to confirm thee, I will compare the noble service of a feast with the honourable service of the field, and then put on thy hand to which thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Thank you good captain, but do you think that war is naught sir?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Exceeding naught.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Why then sir take heed what you say, for 'tis dangerous speaking against any thing that is naught, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Thou sayest wisely lieutenant, I will not then use the word naught, nor speak ill of either, but compare them both, and choose the better.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Take heed then good captain, there be some prick-eared intelligencers conveyed into some wall or other about us.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: If there were I care not, for to say true, the first model of a battle was taken from a banquet. And first touching the offices of both: for the general of the field, there is the master of the feast, for the lieutenant general, the mistress, for the sergeant maior, the steward, for the gentleman usher, the marshal, for master oth' ordinance the sewer, and all other officers.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Yet you're reasonable well captain.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Then for the preparation, as in a field is all kind of artillery, your cannon, your demi-canon, culverings, falcons, sacres, minions, and such goodly ornaments of a field, I speak no hurt of 'em thou seest, I'll have nothing to do do with 'Am.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Hold you still there captain.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p:
Besides other munition of powder and shot, and so for
the feast, you have your court, cupboards planted with flagons, cans, cups, beakers, bowls, goblets, basins and ewers: and more glorious show I wiss then the tother, and yet I speak no hurt of the other.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: No I'll be sworn captain.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Besides your munition of manchet, nappery plaits, spoons, glasses and so forth; then for your kitchen artillery, there shall you see all your brass pieces mounted in order, as your beef-pots, your cauldrons, your kettles, chafingdishes, ladies, spits, a more edifying spectacle than your cannon and culvering, and yet I speak no hurt of them neither.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: No captain, thus far, I go we.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Then sir, as in the field the drum, so to the feast the dresser gives the alarm, ran tan tara, tan tan tantara tan.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: O how it stirs my stomach?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: First then sets forward a wing of light horse, as salads, broths, sauces, flewed meats, and other kickshores ▪ and they give a charge, then do the battle join captain capon in white-brith, lieutenant calf's head.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: That's my place.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Ancient Surloigne, a man of a goodly presence, and full of expectation, as you ancient ought to be, then have you sergeant Tear-cat, corporal Conny, lancepresado lark, gentlemen, panbakex, and all the species of a company.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Would we might fall to the fight once.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why now grows the fight hot man, now shall you see many a tall piece of beef, many a tough capon go down, and here's the trial of a man's stomach, all the while the artillery plays on both hands, the canons lay about them, the flagons go off, thick and threefold, and many a tall man goes halting off, some quite overthrown both horse and foot.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: O my heart bleeds.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p:
That is, thy teeth water. In conclusion, as the remnant of the feast, (I mean such dishes as 'scaped the fury of the fight) if they be serviceable, are reserved to furnish out another day if they be maimed or spoilt, they are sent abroad to relieve prisons and hospitals. So the remainder of the fight, if they be serviceable, they are reserved to supply a second field, for the
fragments of the fight, viz. the maimed soldiers, they are sent likewise to furnish prisons and hospitals, how sayest thou now lieutenant, shall we to the feast, or to the fight?

sp.speaker: Inn.
sp.p: No fighting good captain, to the feast for god's sake.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Thou'rt a my mind right, and so will we presently march on to the sack of the emperor's head, then to the may-night feast, and show at signior Honorio's, and there will be a wench there boy, a delicate young morsel, a kinswoman of signior Honorio's, and her father's only child, he a mighty rich clarissimo, and her shalt thou court, win her and wear her, thou hast wit at will.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: But shall that wench be her father's son and heir captain?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: She shall be his heir, a mine honesty.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: But shall not my mistress your wife be at that show?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: She shall, and we could find her; Fannio has been abroad this hour to seek her: the ass is stepped into some corner or other mourning for my absence. (Enter Angelo and Francischina in disguise.)see who comes here?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Come coz, march fair, methinks thou becomest a page excellent naturally, cheer up thy heart wench. Kiss her.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Fie for shame kiss in the streets?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Why not? truth seeks no corners, and 'twas a true love's kiss, and so is this.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Ware riot, dost thou mark lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: God's pity, my husband. Exeunt Franc. Ang.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: What were these captain?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Upon my life the hindermost of them, is a wench in man's attire, didst thou not mark besides his slabbering about her, her big thighs and her splay feet.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: By the meskin methought they were so indeed.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: 'Slife, the hungry knave her squire, could not hold in the open streets.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: What should she be?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: The doxy was muffled in her cloak, I had but a glimpse of her; but 'slight I will know her, she passes not so, come we'll follow. I'll beat the rogue and take away's whore from him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Come courage coz, we have sailed the man of war out of sight, and here we must put into harbour. Hist, hawe Amila?

sp.speaker: Amil.
sp.p: O welcome good Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Here take in, go, get up lightly, away, take heed you slip not coz, remember you're short heeled.

sp.speaker: F●anc.
sp.p: Hold fast for God's sake.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay hold you fast, you'll shame us all else; so Jove receive thy soul: I take away the ladder: now till you have deceived the Provost, farewell, remember your lesson coz. Exit.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: I warrant you. (Enter Quintil. and Innocentio)

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: How unhappily did we miss 'em? they slipped into some vaulting house, I hold my life.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Faith it's good we missed 'em, she was some stale punk I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Twenty to one she is some honest man's wife of the parish that steals abroad for a trimming, while he sits secure at home, little knowing, God knows, what hangs over his head; the poor cuckold esteeming her the most virtuous wife in the world. And should one tell him, he had seen her dressed like a page following a knave thus, I'll lay my life he would not believe it.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Why no captain, wives take all the faith from their husbands. And that makes 'em do so many good works as they do.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Mercy for that i'faith lieutenant, stand close. (Enter Fannio and Giacono)

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: My mistress in man's apparel sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: Thy mistress in man's apparel I assure thee, and attended by Angelo.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: Would to heaven I had seen her, canst tell whither she went.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: Full butt into Lorenzo's house, and if thou knewest him, thou knowest wherefore, an ill-favoured trimming is her errand.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p:
'Tis very well, she trims my captain prettily, in the
mean time his head pays for all, and yet alas poor hornstock, he thinks her to have no fault, but her too much dotage upon him, well my conscience will not let me keep her counsel, he shall know on't.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: Why man if both of us should tell him her fault he will not believe us.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: No, nor if he had seen it with his own own eyes I think, I shall never forget how the profound cockatrice hung on his sleeve today, and he should not from her sight, she'd follow him into the wars, one day should make an end of both their loves and lives, and then to see him the wittal, my captain began to strut, and battle the pride of his merits that so heightened her affection.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: True, and how the foppasty his lieutenant, stepped in to persuade with her, to take it patiently, for friends must part, we came not all together, and we must not go all together.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: Well, 'twill not be for any man to follow him, if this were known once.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: Lord how all the boys in the town would flock about him as he walks the streets, as 'twere about a bagpipe, and hoot the poor cuckold out of his horncase.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: Well, and I were worthy to give him counsel, he should e'en fair and well hang himself.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: No, no, keep it from him, and say thou foundest her at a woman's labour.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: A plague of her labour, the captain's brows sweat while she labours.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: If I were in thy case, I should laugh out right when I saw him.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: That dare not I do, but as often as he turns his back to me, I shall be here v with him that's certain: or when I follow him and his cheating stock Innocentio, in the streets, I shall imagine still I am driving an ox and an ass before me, and cry phtroh, ho● ptrough.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: 'Slight captain take this and take all.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p:
Not a word for the world, for if we should take notice of his words the slave would deny all, leave it to me to sift it in private. Now sir, what news with you? where's your mistress,
that you range thus at your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: In health sir I trust.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Come forward you rogue you: come forward, whither creep you behind so? where's your mistress sir?

sp.speaker: Fann
sp.p: At a poor woman's labour sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Very well sir, come lieutenant, go you afore, and do you follow him sir.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: What afore my captain sir: you shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Qu●nt..
sp.p: Afore you rogue, afore.Exeunt

div.head: Actus quintus.
div.stage: Enter Honorio, Lorenzo, Gasparo and Angelo.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Signior Lorenzo, and Gasparo, you're very welcome, we shall have good company and sport to entertain you ere long I hope, shall we not Angelo?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Yes sir, I have invited all you commanded me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: This is the honest man indeed, that took the pains to come for me.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: And for me also.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: No pains but pleasure sir, I was glad I had such good means to be known to your worship.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Nay, I have known you before, to be the servant of signior Honorio here, I take it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Not my servant signior Lorenzo, but my sons.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: O, your son Aurelio's servant? believe me you or your son (In mine opinion, though I say it before him) made good choice of him: for he hath a good honest face, and to a man of judgement (I tell you) that's as good as a good surety for him. I will be better acquainted with you sir, pray you give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Both my hand and heart sir, shall be ever at your service.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Thanks my good friend, I'll make thee laugh anon Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I thank your worship, you have done so often.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: A notable wag signior Gasparo.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: How curiously Lorenzo thinks he carries the matter?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How now gentlemen, is't a merry secret, that you smile so?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: No secret signior Lorenzo, but a merry conceit we were thinking on, to furnish our show anon, if it had been thought on in time.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What was that I pray?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Marry sir, we had good sport today with snail the chimney-sweeper.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Had you so sir?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: That ever was.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Lord that I had been amongst you, but what more of him sir?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Marry sir, we were thinking how we might merrily deceive our company that is to come, if we could have gotten him some magnificoes suit of the city, whom for his little stature and lean face he might resemble, that in that habit he might have stolen some kind favours from the ladies, to make him amends and please him for the anger we put him in.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: It would have made excellent merriment.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: You are his best master sir, and if it please you to send me for him by some token, I'll go for him; otherwise he will not come to these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Shall he come gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: If you please sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Why then heark thee Angelo; not for the world.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Think you me such an ass sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Shall he have one of my little brother's suits, and come in amongst the dames for him?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: If you could, it would fit him exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Much; now laugh Angelo: what gentleman was that I spied aloft with my daughter think'st thou?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I know not sir; I beseech your worship who was it?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Frank, in man's apparel Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: O wonderful.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: We cannot invent a token, for my love Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: O excellent.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: We will hit it anon gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: At your leisure sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: The swaggerer her husband, had note of it by his page, and yet the same page hath persuaded him, since that 'twas but a gullery.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: 'Tis a notable crack; and his master hath such a pure belief in his wife, that he's apt to believe any good of her.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: True Angelo, enough for this time; thou shalt make as if thou wentest for snail, and return without him, saying thou canst not find him.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Agreed sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Now gentlemen, we have devised a wile to bring snail amongst us, and I have given Angelo order for a suit for him, that is my little brothers, and him he shall counterfeit; go Angelo seek him out.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I will sir. Exit Ang.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Thank you for this good signior Lorenzo.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: It will quicken the company well. Enter Aemilia, Lionell, Francischina and another woman.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: For their sakes and yours, I have done it gentlemen; and see the fair flock come upon us.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Welcome fair ladies, but especially you lady, that are so mere a stranger, signior Lorenzo you know young Leonoro?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Very well sir, a gallant spark.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: And I think you know his father.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Know him? I'faith sir there was a reveller, I shall never see man do his lofty tricks like him while I live.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: This gentlewoman is his niece sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: His niece? she shall do herself wrong not to be acquainted with her dear uncle's companion:Kiss her.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: You know not this gentlewoman sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Not very well sir indeed, but entertainment must be given, mercy Frank for thy man's apparel, a plague of all
swaggering husbands. Nay I must forth i'faith, signior Honorio ▪ this is for your sake, am I not a kind help to your entertainment?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: An exceeding kind one sir, and I exceedingly thank you. (Enter messenger.)

sp.speaker: M●ss
sp.p: The maskers are come sir.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Do you and your fellows attend them in.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: We will sir. Exit mess.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Sit gentle ladies till the maskers raise you to dance.

div.stage: Enter Aurelio, Leonoro, Quintiliano, and Innocentio, in a mask dancing.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Welcome gallants, oh the room's too scant, a hall gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: See how womanly my boy looks Quintiliano.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: 'Twill be rare sport; lieutenant, that sweet wench in the branched gown is the heir I told thee of.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: God's me, I'll to her and kiss her.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: O no, you must not unmask.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: No, no, I'll kiss her with my mask and all.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No lieutenant, take her and court her first, and then kiss her.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: To her slave.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: There's thy wife too, Quintiliano ▪

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: True, little knows she I am so near her; I'll single her out, and try what entertainment a stranger may find with her.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Do so, and we'll take up the tother. (Enter Angelo.)

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I can by no means find snail sir.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: The worse luck, but what remedy?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Gramercy Angelo ▪ but signior Lorenzo, methinks I miss one flower in this female garland.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Your niece Lucretia ▪

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: By my soul 'tis true; what's the reason Angelo Lucretia is not here?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I know no reason but her own will sir.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: There's somewhat in it certain. They dance again.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Did you see the play today I pray?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: No, but I see the fool in it here.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Do you so forsooth? where is he pray?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Not far from you sir, but we must not point at anybody here.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: That's true indeed, cry mercy forsooth, do you know me through my mask?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Not I sir ▪ she must have better skill in baked meats then I, that can discern a woodcock through the crust.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: That's true indeed, but yet I thought I'd try you. (Enter Lodouico.) They dance.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What nephew Lodwick, I thought you had been one of the maskers.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I use no masking sir with my friends.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: No signior Lodowick, but you're a very truant in your school of friendship ▪ that come so late to your friends.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Somewhat has crossed him sure.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Somewhat shall cross him; Lodovico let me speak with you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: With me sir?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You are the man sir, I can scarce say the gentleman, for you have done a wrong the credit of a gentleman cannot answer.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Would I might see his face, that durst say so much.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Observe him well, he shoes his face that will prove it when thou dar'st.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: How now Leonoro, you forget yourself too much, to grow outrageous in this company.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Aurelio, do not wrong me, and yourself, I undertake your quarrel, this man hath dishonoured your kinswoman Lucretia, whom (If I might) I intended to marry.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Some error makes you mistake Leonoro, I assure myself.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What interruption of our sport is this gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Are not my nephew and Leonoro friends?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: He charges me with dishonouring his mistress Lucretia.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: By’r lady Lodovico, the charge touches you deeply, you must answer it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I only desire I may sir, and then will refer me to your censures.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Well nephew, well; will you never leave this your haunt of fornication? I school him, and do all I can, but all is lost.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Good uncle give me leave to answer my other accuser, and then I'll descend, and speak of your fornication, as the last branch of my division.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Very well, be brief.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I will sir; the ground upon which this man builds his false imagination, is his sight of me at Honorio's back gate, since dinner, where muffled in my cloak, kind madam temperance, the attendant of Lucretia, from the terrace, wafted me to her with her hand; taking me (As now I understand) for this honest gentleman, I not knowing what use she had to put me to, obeyed the attraction of her signal, as gingerly as she bade me. (A plague upon her gingerly) till she locked me into Lucretia's chamber, where Lucretia lying asleep on her bed, I thought it rudeness to wake her; and (Imagining when she waked she had something to say to me) attended her leisure at my ease, and lay down softly by her; when (Having chaster and simpler thoughts than Leonoro imagines) because he measures my waste by his own) in the very coldness and dulness of my spirit, I fell suddenly asleep. In which my fancy presented me with the strangest dream, that ever yet possessed me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Pray God you did but dream nephew.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: You shall know that by knowing the event of it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Go to, pray let us hear it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: methought Lucretia and I were at maw, a game uncle that you can well skill of.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Well sir I can so.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: You will the more muse at my fortune; or my oversights. For my game stood, methought , upon my last two tricks, when I made sure of the set, and yet lost it, having the varlet and the five finger to make two tricks.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How had that been possible?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: That had been no misfortune sure but plain oversight.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: But what was the reason you thought you lost it sir?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: You shall hear; she had in her hand the ace of hearts, methought , and a coat-card, she led the board with her coat, I played the varlet, and took up her coat, and meaning to lay my five finger upon her ace of hearts, up start a quite contrary card; up she rises withal, takes me a dash a the mouth, drew a rapier he had lie by him, and out of doors we went together by the ears.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: A rapier he had lie by him?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What a she turned to a he? dost thou not dream all this while nephew.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No nor that time neither, though I pretended it; let him be fetched, I warrant you he will show as good cards as the best on you, to prove him an heir male, if he be the eldest child of his father.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: This is exceeding strange: go Angelo, fetch her and her handmaid.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I will sir, if her valour be not too hot for my fingers. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Could such a disguise be made good all this while without my knowledge? to say truth, she was a stranger to me, her father being a sicilian: fled thence for a disastrous act, and coming hither grew kindly acquainted with me, and called me brother. At his death committing his supposed daughter to my care and protection, till she were restored to her estate in her native country.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Was he in hope of it?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: He was, and in near possibility of it himself, had he lived but little longer. (Enter Angelo and Lucretia.)

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Here's the gentlewoman you talked of sir, nay you must come forward too grave mistress Temperance.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How now sir? who wants gentility now I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Who have we here?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Stand not amazed, nor disparage him: you see sir, this habit truly doth suit my sex, howsoever my hard fortunes have made me a while reject it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What hard fortunes?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Those you know of my father sir: who feared my following of him in my native likeness, to the haven, where he by stealth embarked us, and would have discovered him, his offence being the slaughter of a gentleman, that would have slain him.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: But did you not tell me you were betrothed before this misfortune happened, to a young gentleman of Sicily, called Theagines?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: I told you I was betrothed to one Theagine, not Theagines, who indeed was a woman,

sp.speaker: L●o.
sp.p: And yet whosoever had seen that Theagine since might have taken him for a man.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Do you know her gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: L●o.
sp.p: It seems you will not know her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Hark how my boy plays the knave with her.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: A noble rogue, 'sfoot lieutenant, wilt thou suffer thy nose to be wiped of this great heir?

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: 'Slight sir you are no handkercher are you?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Pre thee forbear, more happy than unlooked for 〈◊〉 this dear accident: adopted and noble father, this is the gentlewoman to whom I told you I was betrothed, the happy news she had to relate to me, made her a traveller, the more search of her passage made her a page, and her good fortune obtained her — this honest gentleman to her master, who I thank him, being (As he supposed me) loved me, accept us both for your children.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: Most gladly and with no less care, than mine own protect you.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, how now Leonora? new fireworks?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: New sir, who wants gentility? this is a gentlemanly part of you to keep a wench in a page's furniture?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: It was more than I knew sir, but this shall be a warning to me while I live, how I judge of the instrument by the case again.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Nay it is you friend Lodovico that are most to blame, that holding the whole feminine sex in such contempt, would yet play the pickpurse, and steal a poor maid's maidenhead out of her pocket sleeping.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Twas but to cozen me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And to be before me in love.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: And to laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay, jest not at me sweet gentles, I used plain and mannerly dealing, I neither used the brokage of any ▪ as you know who did Leonoro, nor the help of a ladder to creep in at a wench's chamber window (As you know who did Aurelio.) Nor did I case myself in buckram, and cry chimney sweep (Where are you uncle?) but I was trained to it by this honest matron here.

sp.speaker: Temperance
sp.p: Meddle not with me sir.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: I am beholding to her, she was loath to have me lead apes in hell.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Look that you keep promise with me lady, when will thy husband be from home?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Not so soon as I would wish him, but whensoever you shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: I very kindly thank you lady.

sp.speaker: Fr●n.
sp.p: God's me, I took you for signior Placentia.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, thou liest in thy throat, thou knewest me as well as myself.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: What, signior Quintilian, and friend Innocentio? I looked not for you here ▪ and you're much the better welcome.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: Thanks dad Honorio, and lives my little squire? when shall I see thee at my house lad?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A plague a your house, I was there too lately.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: See lordings, here's two will not let go till they have your consents to be made surer.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: By my soul, and because old Gasparo here has been so cold in his love suit, if she be better pleased with Aurelio, and his father with her, heaven give abundance of good with him.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: So you stand not too much upon goods, I say, amen.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Faith use him as your son and heir, and I desire no more.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: So will I of mine honour, are you agreed youths ▪

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: And most humbly gratulate your high favours.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Faith and Jove give 'em joy together for my part.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yet is here another nail to be driven, here's a virtuous matron, madam Temperance, that is able to do much good in a commonwealth, a woman of good parts, sells complexion helps maids to services, restores maidenheads, brings women to bed, and men to their bedsides.

sp.speaker: Temperance
sp.p: By my faith, but save votre grace sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hath drinks for love, and gives the diet.

sp.speaker: Temperance
sp.p: By’r lady, and that's not amiss for you sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: For me, with a plague tee?

sp.speaker: Temperance
sp.p: No nor for any man that's not sound I mean sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'Sfoot masters these be good parts in the old wench, wilt thou have her lieutenant? she'll be a good stay to the rest of thy living, the gallants will all honour thee at thy house I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Fore God captain I care not if I have.

sp.speaker: Temperance
sp.p: Well young gentleman, perhaps it should not be the worst for you.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why la, thy virtues have owned her at first sight, she shall not come to thee empty, for I'll promise thee that I'll make her able to bid any gentleman welcome to a piece of mutton and rabbit at all times.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: By’r lady, a good ordinary.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Though't visit sometimes dad.

sp.speaker: Lor
sp.p: That I will i'faith boy in authority wise.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Why then strike hands, and if the rest be pleased,
Let all hands strike as these have struck afore,
And with round echoes make the welkin roar. Exeunt.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
